Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Phase I Robert Noyce Teacher Education Scholarship Program at Vassar College is recruiting, preparing, and certifying 14 high-achieving STEM majors to become K-12 science and mathematics teachers in high-need schools. The program builds on Vassar's rigorous undergraduate STEM programs, a teacher education program that emphasizes leadership, and well-established STEM outreach programs with local high-need schools. The Vassar Program includes four critical elements: scholarships for 14 high-achieving Vassar STEM majors during their junior and senior years and for completion of student teaching the fall following graduation; summer science education and research internships; pre-professional activities in partnership with high-need districts in the City of Poughkeepsie and Hyde Park, NY; and, support for early career professional development in collaboration with the Consortium for Excellence in Teacher Education. Vassar STEM faculty members and local K-12 STEM educators are mentoring the Noyce Scholars.

This program is increasing the number of Vassar STEM majors entering K-12 STEM education in high-need districts, improving the quality of STEM education in those districts, and producing leaders in K-12 STEM education. These new teachers also motivate students from under-served groups to raise their educational aspirations, including the college-level study of mathematics and science. The program is designed as a model that can be replicated at predominantly undergraduate institutions with strong STEM programs and high-ability students with an interest in K-12 education in under-served communities, who typically leave the immediate area after graduation to teach in schools in large metropolitan areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Vassar College Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship had as its goal to recruit, certify and retain high-achieving STEM majors to become K-12 science and mathematics teachers in high-need schools. The Program aimed to increase the number of STEM majors serving K-12 students in high-need districts, improve the quality of STEM education in those districts, and produce leaders in STEM education. It would have a significant multiplier effect as these teachers work in high-need districts and thereby prepare and motivate students from under-served groups to raise their educational aspirations, including the college-level study of mathematics and science. The Program also was intended to be a model applicable to primarily undergraduate institutions located in rural areas or small communities where new teaching positions are limited, and who train new teachers who leave the immediate area to teach primarily in large metropolitan areas.

The Vassar Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, as outlined in the proposal to the National Science Foundation, aimed (1) to recruit 14 Vassar STEM majors to become Noyce Scholars, who would make a commitment to teach in a high-need district for two years for each year of scholarship, and (2) to select 26 Noyce Summer Interns for STEM to undertake K-12 STEM education related projects that would deepen their interest in exploring teaching as a career. By all measures, the Vassar Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program has been a complete success.

Twenty-seven Vassar Noyce Summer Internships were awarded under the grant. Students found a wide variety of appealing summer STEM-education related opportunities. These include:  an internship in the Education Department of the Smithsonian Air and Space Museum; participation in Vassar's "Exploring College" program, a summer program to boost college readiness and aspirations among high-achieving, low-income students; serving as an instructor in a summer engineering camp at USC under the auspices of  a non-profit organization that  provides math and science outreach programs to underrepresented communities; acting as a team leader in the Math and Science Through Excellence and Research (MASTER) Program housed at the Lehman College campus of CUNY; an internship at the Museum of Science in Boston; teaching at the Brown Environmental Leadership Lab; an internship at the Arizona Science Center; and, an internship at the Cincinnati Observatory where the Vassar Noyce Intern  had an opportunity to learn from excellent informal educators, including a co-host of PBS' Star Gazers series. Moreover, of the 22 summer internships that were awarded prior to the selection of the final cohort of Vassar Noyce Scholars, eight were awarded to students who ultimately applied to become and were selected as Noyce Scholars.

Sixteen Vassar students were awarded Noyce Scholarships, two more than were proposed in the project narrative. All sixteen have now been graduated from Vassar and either have completed their Noyce teaching commitment, are in the process of fulfilling their commitment, or are completing their teaching certification in post-graduate programs. These Vassar Noyce Scholars distinguished themselves at the College---three were elected to Phi Beta Kappa and two others were elected to Sigma XI, the scientific research honor society---and have continued to do so following graduation. One of the important rationales underpinning Vassar’s Noyce proposal is that Vassar students have significant leadership potential. This has been borne out thus far in the honors that Vassar’s Noyce Scholars have earned: a Math for America Fellowship in Los Angeles, a Math for America Early Career Fellowship in New York, a Knowles Teaching Fellowship, and an inaugural Design Fellowship at the Woodrow Wilson Academy of Teaching and Learning at MIT.  Vassar Noyce Scholars also have earned Masters degrees in Mathematics or Science education at Brown University, the Claremont Graduate University, New York University, and the University of Chicago.

The Vassar Noyce Scholarship Program concluded in June 2017 with a conference at Vassar for all Vassar Noyce Scholars, with the theme, “Bulding Our Vassar Noyce Teacher Scholar Community.” The keynote speaker was Megan Roberts, the Executive Director of Math for America. Recognizing the importance of sustaining a professional community to teacher retention, activities at the conference focused on having this talented group of Vassar students from the classes of 2013 through 2017 work together to develop and take concrete steps to build a supportive community of young STEM teachers.
